Topic.Title: Microsoft has to go buy out the largest US manufacturer of industrial robots

Message.Msg: Problem is, that once the facility is built, there are only very few folks needed on site. The only folks that you will need are those that put the parts into the hoppers for the robots to build the equipment, forklift operators to load the trucks, janitors to clean the toilets for the few that will use them, and security guards. Maintaining the equipment will probably be done by the company that manufacturers the equipment, so many a few contractors on site. Probably 98% of the jobs that actually need to be filled for these types of places can easily be handled by the soon to be made legal illegals from Mexico. No real job growth to speak of when heavy robotics are used in the work place to replace people. Robots dont ask for pay increases, they dont ask to use the bathroom, they dont take lunch breaks, they dont need medical plans or 401K plans, exactly why would any company that can highly leverage robotics actually want to create any jobs for humans that it doesnt have to?

Having actionable intelligence and not acting on it then implies complicity in the terrorist act. If you do notihing to stop it, then you are condoining it, pure and simple. Message.Title: Gaming is migrating to the PC
Message.Msg: I have three nephews who are very addicted to gaming. They have been on top of everything XBOX and PS3 ever since they came out. They will not shut up, ever, about Skyrim. One is actually sponsored for competitive gaming in his local town. So when they came up for summer vacation first question I asked was "PS4 or the new XBOX?" Their answer? "None of the above" Every single kid is looking to get a gaming laptop because of Minecraft and the expanded Skyrim titles being moved online. They said the XBOX or PS4 couldn't handle the upcoming processing power needed for these massive games ( of course he was exaggerating, but my one nephew said Bethesda was building a server farm larger than Google. The kids have themselves all worked in a tizzy). This is the 12-16yr old crowd. I'm sure there are plenty of younger gamers in the 6-12 range who still want a console. But food for thought.

Message.Title: Nice pop. Sometimes Softy sells off when it makes a M&A
Message.Msg: Remember the Skype sell off? Well what do you think now that SKYPE with XBOX One will be in HD on a big screen TV right in your living room or board room. Yea I said board room. That is because business will be big buyers of XBOX One. You know how much Cisco charges for the same thing that is same thing just not as good. A secretary can hook up Skype. It is easy and it shows up on the TV screen as an incoming call. Speaking of going down when buying or partnerships, etc. One you have the Oracle news. Oracle has a lot of customers. Also you like the way Skype is continuous rather than off and on waiting up to two minutes. Thank Nokia's NSN division. Not to mention that Nokia sells 87% of all Windows 8 phones. Nokia also provides the Here maps that are integrated in everything Microsoft. Hey I get it that stock go down if they are the buyer, investor, etc. Microsoft needs Nokia period. Remember that. It should not sell off if anything in any way shape or form happens with Nokia. Nokia is killing it as far as tech goes. They have not taken it easy like Apple. Thing are going good. It seems in the past you get a sell of in softy on any type of news. So remember Skype is turning out to be a great thing and everyone growled on the announcement day. Both Microsoft & Nokia or doing not good they are killing it. Oracle is moving in the right direction as opposed to these companies that thing they have it all figured out. Netflix is also helped by Nokias NSN. It is getting interesting.

Message.Title: Partners in the enterprise cloud (Mr. Softy and Oracle)....
Message.Msg: "As longtime competitors, partners and industry leaders, Microsoft and Oracle have worked with enterprise customers to address business and technology needs for over 20 years. Many customers rely on Microsoft infrastructure to run mission-critical Oracle software and have for over a decade. Today, we are together extending our work to cover private cloud and public cloud through a new strategic partnership between Microsoft and Oracle. This partnership will help customers embrace cloud computing by improving flexibility and choice while also preserving the first-class support that these workloads demand. As part of this partnership Oracle will certify and support Oracle software on Windows Server Hyper-V and Windows Azure. That means customers who have long enjoyed the ability to run Oracle software on Windows Server can run that same software on Windows Server Hyper-V or in Windows Azure and take advantage of our enterprise grade virtualization platform and public cloud. Oracle customers also benefit from the ability to run their Oracle software licenses in Windows Azure with new license mobility. Customers can enjoy the support and license mobility benefits, starting today". Folks this is going to be a great catalyst for "Windows 8 Mobility Devices" such as Surface Pro et al.... Osso

Message.Title: Developers, devices and a world of opportunity....
Message.Msg: "The developer ecosystem is undergoing rapid change, having grown from fewer than 20 million professional programmers just 15 years ago to more than 100 million coders today, ranging from pros to citizen developers. And, the opportunity has never been greater: With an explosion of low cost, powerful devices and the access to massive computing and processing power in the cloud, developers are no longer constrained by the hardware or software of a specific device or a local data store. But with opportunity comes the challenges of learning new technologies, fierce competition, and juggling the variety of devices and services in the marketplace. A successful path forward can include navigating any number of difficult choices before an app can generate revenue, create a differentiated experience and provide an efficient return on investment. At Build 2013 this week in San Francisco, we will showcase how developers, app builders and companies of all sizes can create experiences on the Windows platform to engage consumers, empower employees, solve problems and drive companies. Whether developing a client application for the Windows desktop, or building to the modern device and cloud application patterns with Windows 8 and Windows Azure, developers are seeking consistent and flexible platforms".
